December 1, 1991: Fiction
SCARLETT, by Alexandra Ripley. (Warner, $24.95.) The sequel to Margaret
Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind."
NO GREATER LOVE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $23.) The sinking of the
Titanic greatly alters the lives and fortunes of Edwina Winfield and her large
family.
NEEDFUL THINGS, by Stephen King. (Viking, $24.95.) A newcomer opens a
shop in Castle Rock, Me., bringing bargains as well as nightmares and disasters
to the town.
THE SUM OF ALL FEARS, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $24.95.) Middle Eastern
terrorists edge the world to the brink of nuclear war.
THE SAPPHIRE ROSE, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $22.) The third
volume in "The Elenium," a fantasy saga.
COMEBACK, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $21.95.) A diplomat, returning to his
native Gloucestershire, finds that his past life in horse racing may help save
others.
NIGHT OVER WATER, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $23.) High drama on a trans-
Atlantic flight after the outbreak of World War II.
REMEMBER, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Random House, $22.50.) A television
correspondent takes a trip across Europe to learn the truth about her fiance's
suicide.
THE DOOMSDAY CONSPIRACY, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $22.) An
American naval officer, assigned to investigate a balloon accident in the Alps, has
to contend with a mysterious force.
SLEEPING BEAUTY, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $22.) A lawyer returns to her
estranged family to attend a funeral.
ALL THE WEYRS OF PERN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $20.) A
new volume in the science fiction series "The Dragonriders of Pern."
THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that his
firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) Verse
and pictures.
LILA, by Robert M. Pirsig. (Bantam, $22.50.) On a sailboat cruise down the
Hudson with a woman companion, a philosopher reflects on the nature of our
society.
December 1, 1991
Non-Fiction
UNDER FIRE, by Oliver L. North with William Novak. (HarperCollins, $25.) The
autobiography of the retired Marine lieutenant colonel, with his view of the Iran-
contra affair.
ME: Stories of My Life, by Katharine Hepburn. (Knopf, $25.) The actress's
memoirs.
DEN OF THIEVES, by James B. Stewart. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) How Ivan
Boesky, Michael Milken, Martin Siegel and Dennis Levine plundered and created
havoc on Wall Street.
UH-OH, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $19.) Reflections on life's commonplaces.
PRAIRYERTH, by William Least Heat-Moon. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.)
A close look at the people and mores, past and present, of Chase County,
Kansas.
THE NEW WORLD ORDER, by Pat Robertson. (Word Publishing, $17.99.) A
clergyman discusses the significance of global changes.
CHILDHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Putnam, $14.95.) The entertainer recalls his
boyhood and reflects on the ways of today's kids.
PARLIAMENT OF WHORES, by P. J. O'Rourke. (Entrekin/Atlantic Monthly,
$19.95.) A humorist's attempt to explain the Federal Government.
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures.
MOLLY IVINS CAN'T SAY THAT, CAN SHE? by Molly Ivins. (Random House,
$23.) Essays about the current political and cultural scene by the Texas journalist.
CRUEL DOUBT, by Joe McGinniss. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The ordeal of a
North Carolina woman whose son was accused of planning the murder of herself
and her husband.
FIRE IN THE BELLY, by Sam Keen. (Bantam, $19.95.) A philosopher explores the
changing role of the male in today's society.
DANCE WHILE YOU CAN, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $22.50.) The actress
examines her feelings about relationships, aging and the future.
BACKLASH, by Susan Faludi. (Crown, $24.) A journalist contends that the media,
the fashion and beauty industries and political groups are staging a war against
women's rights.
WHEN YOU LOOK LIKE YOUR PASSPORT PHOTO, IT'S TIME TO GO HOME,
